explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible, because of the unidentified configuration and the absence of data. The substance, in the form of powder or vapor, is flammable (ICSC (2004)) and, as far as metals are concerned, the finer the particles, the more dangerous they are, according to Sax (11th, 2004). Metal powder (combustibles) (except those identifiable by name) is classified into Divisions 4.1, Packing Group II and III (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#3089).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: The substance is stable in the air at ordinary temperatures (Merck (13th, 2001)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The substance is stable in the air and does not react with water (Merck (13th, 2001))

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing no oxygen and halogen

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Because the rat LD50 (oral route) values of >=9,000mg/kg (ECETOC TR33 (1989)) and >=5,000mg/kg (ECETOC TR33 (1989)) exceed 5,000mg/kg.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified into "Respiratory Sensitizing Substance: Group 2" according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)) and "Respiratory Sensitizing Substance" by the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy and DFG.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified into "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1" according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)) and Skin Sensitizing Substance by the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy and DFG.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to the insufficiency of data (no data available on in vivo mutagenicity/genotoxicity tests)

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R (as metal nickel) by NTP (2005), Category 2B (as metal nickel) by IARC (1990).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (respiratory system, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "alveolar wall damage, alveolar edema and significant renal tubular necrosis" (ATSDR (2005)). The acute toxicity of nickel compounds manifests in humans as "nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache" (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system)
aspiration_hazard.rationale:
The respiratory organs are considered to be the target organs since there are reports on adverse effects such as "pleurisy, pneumonia, congestion, and edema"(CaPSAR (1994)) and then "focal accumulation of alveolar macrophages and interstitial"(ATSDR (2005)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance values for Category 1 in the chronic studies. Therefore, the substance was classified as Category 1 (respiratory organs).
The chronic toxicity of nickel compounds in humans is mentioned as follows: "Chronic exposure to nickel and its compounds may produce respiratory irritation and degeneration in humans even at doses close to occupational exposure limits. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations is likely to result in the fibroid lung"(ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: May cause long lasting harmful effects to aquatic life
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although L(E) C50 <=100 mg/L data existed, since it was metal and the behavior in the water was unknown, it classified into Category 4.
